The Post Office formerly limited its provision of new line plant for such subscribers to that justified by the number of units left after deducing from the fresh allocation the number of units represented by existing departmental line plant used to connect the subscriber to the new automatic exchange. Under this arrangement some subscribers received relatively little new departmental line plant for their automatic services.

The new interpretation means that subscribers whose local exchange is being converted to automatic get the full benefit of the fresh allocation of ninety-six units from the end of existing departmental construction. For example, the effect on a group of nine subscribers at Shelford, about which the honourable senator made representations earlier, is that six will receive wholly departmental lines without cost to them. For the remaining three, contributions required to meet line costs have been very substantially reduced. Subscribers being transferred from adjacent exchanges to a new automatic exchange receive similar benefits. Those who do not obtain wholly departmental lines will have shorter private sections of lines than before.

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Shipping and Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: As far as is known, all windscreens fitted to motor vehicles in Australia are manufactured to a safety glass standard. The most commonly used safety glass is a heat treated variety which, upon impact, can obscure the view of the driver. The standard has recently been changed to require this type of glass to incorporate a zone through which vision can be maintained. Most manufacturers now use this zoned safety glass.

answer.para: For this reason and as the Australian Transport Advisory Council has agreed that all motor vehicles manufactured after 1st January 1970, and to be registered in Australia, shall be required to meet the new safety standard, an inquiry would serve no useful purpose.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for External Affairs, upon notice:

item.para: What progress has been made in the survey of the common boundary between the Territory of Papua' and New Guinea and West Irian?
How much of the boundary has actually been marked on the ground?
When is the survey likely to be completed?
When is the actual border, as finally marked and agreed to, likely to be ratified by the Australian Government and the West Irian authorities?

talk.start.para: The Minister for External Affairs has provided the following answer:

item.label: 1 to 4.
item.para: Australian and Indonesian survey teams completed in 1967 a joint operation involving the positioning of fourteen concrete meridian markers along the length of the border between West Irian and Papua-New Guinea. The survey authorities of both countries are now each marking on air photographs theline which the border should be deemed to follow between these markers. When this is complete a further meeting will be held between the survey authorities to draw up a report to the two Governments on the basis of the agreed results. Further steps actually to mark the border on the ground will depend upon future agreement between the two Governments.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for External Affairs, upon notice:

quote.para: Will the Minister inform the Parliament at an early date of the proposals now being formulated by Japanese business and financial circles for economic aid to South Vietnam once peace has been achieved?

talk.start.para: The Minister for External Affairs has furnished the following reply.

answer.para: The Government is aware of recent suggestions emanating from Japanese business circles that planning should now commence on programmes to provide economic assistance to Vietnam following a cessation of hostilities. These suggestions, as they are known to the Government, have been sketched in broad outline only. The Government does not know of any precise and detailed plans that may have been formulated by any Japanese business groups.

This whole matter, which is a very complex one, is being kept under close study by the Australian Government. It is relevant to the question to recall that at the last meeting of the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East in Singapore, the Vietnamese Minister of Public Works announced details of a recently completed report on the postwar development of Vietnam. This report was submitted by an agency known as the Joint Development Group, established 2 years ago by the Vietnamese and United States governments to study possible policies and programmes for a 10-year post-war period looking to the achievement of economic independence. Although the findings of the report are too long to be condensed in this answer, it will be of interest to honourable senators to note that the foreign aid requirement of Vietnam over this period is estimated at $US2.5 billion out of a total investment of $US5.1 billion. It is very likely that this report will provide much of the framework for any postwar plan for national development adopted by the Vietnamese Government. It can be assumed therefore that business and financial groups in Japan will take the report into account in formulating any precise proposals for their future activities in Japan.
